results.title: Bingo, bridesmaids and braces
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Tristram Miall and Gillian Armstrong
results.brief_description: In this documentary the lives of three working class women are examined as they grow up from the “not so innocent” age of fourteen, to “it’s happening too fast” at eighteen, through to “well we survived”, at the ripe young age of 26. During these years we witness the women confronting the very real issues of teenage pregnancy, love versus sex, and career choices.

results.title: Binary bit patterns
results.creator_credit: Michael Whitney, Information International and Motion Graphics and Pyramid Films
results.brief_description: This film puts a musical backing to a kaleidoscope of regular and abstract patterns based on geometric computer forms. Rapid movement of these ever-changing images is created with variations in colour and visual effect. Suitable for secondary years 7-12.

results.title: Bim (K)
results.creator_credit: Georges Derocles, L'Ecran des Jeunes and Albert Lamorisse
results.brief_description: Bim is the first achievement of director, Albert Lamorisse and, as in the case of Crin Blanc and his latest release ‘The Red Balloon’, he has made a delightful film. Photographed in Algiers, it tells of the adventures of a donkey and his youthful, affectionate owner. Lamorisse is one of those film makers who have a camera eye, that is the gift of pointing the camera lens to obtain pictures of infinite expressiveness. The most distinguished director in this field is Robert Flaherty. The story is that long ago in a far off Eastern Island, it was the custom for each child to have a baby donkey as a pet. One day the son of the Prince was riding haughtily through the streets when he took a fancy to Bim, the donkey belonging to a poor boy called Abdallah. The guards kidnapped Bim, who found himself a prisoner, condemned to death for eating the Great Prince’s dinner, Bim was rescued by thieves who raided the island for animals. After a thrilling chase on land and sea, Abdallah and his friends managed to rescue Bim and all ended happily. Narrated by William Bledsoe.

results.title: Billy's helicopter ride
results.brief_description: Introduces the helicopter and its uses through the story of a young boy taking his first ride. Gives children an opportunity to experience second-hand what they might never experience themselves.

results.title: Billion dollar bubble: the true story of the biggest fraud of all time (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation, Horizon (GB), Horizon Films (AU) and Brian Gibson
results.brief_description: A re-enactment of one of the biggest frauds of all time. In 1969, the Equity Funding Corporation of America lacked the facts to make an accurate profit forecast because of computer troubles. They made a guess - two million dollars too optimistic. So two young executives fed fictitious insurance polices in the computer - all prefixed “99” so that they could easily be cancelled when the temporary loan was paid off. But the temptation to escalate the fraud became irresistible. Cast includes James Woods, Bill Hootkins, Shane Rimmer, Sam Wanamaker, Christopher Guest and Lionel Murton. Script by Tom Clarke.

results.title: Billal
results.creator_credit: Tom Zubrycki, Australian Film Commission, ABC-TV (Australia) and AFFC
results.brief_description: Tom Zubrycki was intending to make a documentary film about unemployed youth in Sydney’s western suburbs when he came across the Etters, a Lebanese Muslim family who had migrated to Australia. What was initially meant to be a film exploring migration and class relationships in urban Australia became something else when the second son, Billal, was the victim of a racially motivated attack which left him brain damaged. As Zubrycki allows his camera to explore each individual family member’s response to the accident, the film becomes an exploration of grief and suffering, and a tribute to the young man’s attempt to adjust to his new situation. Billal and his family infuse their stories with humour and insight, and as the film explores Billal’s rehabilitation, it also becomes an absurd commentary on the under-resourced Australian public health system. “Billal” is then a documentary which is largely about family, and of how a family deals with the tragic consequences of violence. But it is also, of course, a documentary which with subtlety and piquancy, illuminates the destructive effects of racism.

results.title: Bill Tilden's advanced tennis
results.creator_credit: New Official Films and Julian Peyser
results.brief_description: Bill Tilden narrates and demonstrates advanced techniques of tennis, including net game, foot work, smash, service and volley. Front, back, aside and overhead views permit study of his playing technique from a variety of angles.
